title: Aligning Spoken Dialogue Models from User Interactions
author: Anne Wu (Cornell University), Laurent Mazare (Kyutai), Neil Zeghidour (Kyutai), Alexandre Defossez (Kyutai), ...
relevance_why: The methods for aligning dialogue models with real-time spoken interactions could significantly enhance Haohe Liu's research in speech and audio processing, particularly in developing systems that better understand and generate human-like responses.
background: Developing frameworks to enhance spoken dialogue systems by learning from user interactions in real-time conversations.
contribution: This paper introduces a novel preference alignment framework to improve spoken dialogue models by leveraging feedback from user interactions, achieving improvements in factual accuracy and safety.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous alignment methods focused on text-based models, often neglecting the unique complexities of spoken dialogue and real-time interactions.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work specifically addresses the dynamics of spoken conversations, including interruptions and overlapping speech, enabling better human-computer interaction.

key_innovation: It uniquely integrates both linguistic and temporal feedback from real-time user interactions to enhance spoken dialogue models.
real_world_impact: This framework could lead to more effective and engaging voice interfaces in various applications, impacting customer support, personal assistants, and educational tools.
limitations: The study relies on offline data collection and may need further adaptation for online learning environments.

new_terms.full-duplex: **Full-duplex** communication allows both parties to communicate simultaneously, improving the natural flow of conversation.
new_terms.offline alignment: **Offline alignment** refers to the process of adjusting model parameters based on previously collected data rather than in real-time.
